Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 07:44PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Dusty It is good that you are going to see a surgeon.  However, I will err a little on the side of caution here.  If your original ultra sound came back clear, and I understand your concerns, I have had them myself, a biopsy may not solve your concerns.  I have ongoing issues, since I went on this journey, and I still have tenderness, a new benign problem from an excisional biopsy...  So while biopsies are necessary for masses that are picked up, please bear in my mind that biopsies in themselves, can cause problems.  I am my own advocate, and because I have a benign condition, as a result of surgery, I am very much reluctant to have any further needles in me, as a result of 8 procedures in the last three months. So, yes, you can ask for a biopsy, but unecessary ones can produce a whole new set of problems.
Posts.Title: Can I ask for a biopsy? dustyGreen dustyGreen

Posts.Content: May 20, 2012 10:30PM Sommer43 wrote: Right.  Because the radiologist has stated that your ultra sound is "normal" in that there were no abnormalities picked up, you feel that he/she should dig deeper into what is going on?  Your armpit pain could be something totally unrelated to any breast issues you have going on.  My armpit discomfort was what took me to be investigated in the first place.  Those issues have not been alleviated.  Yet, I have had a general anaesthetic, two FNA and three core biopsies and I am now left with another benign tumour, and certainly pain, hot flashes, vaginal dryness, mood swings.  I have been blood tested, my FSH levels are high.  I am in menopause, definitely.  All my ultra sounds came back "probably benign" and I am supposed to return in September for a follow up.  In the meantime, I have used this journey to practice what I have learned, cut down the caffeine which was my main vice, and while I still have caffeine, I am not drinking as much.  It will be very hard for the surgeon to biopsy anything unless he can feel something that needs to be biopsied, if you have seen three doctors who have found nothing, then a 4th is likely to find very little different.  A biopsy of what?  The skin thickening?  All that you have going on, is not "normal" I had to find what my "normal" was, I believe I have found it, I have lumpy breasts, I have dense breasts, I have painful breasts that I have had for years.  Go see the breast surgeon and get the reassurance that is needed, I hope you secure that, but if he states everything is normal, where will you end it all? You might simply have nothing more than hormonal changes going on and busy breasts like I have, and many other women.  I do think from what you have written, that you need to find out if your issues are natural changes or changes that indicate something?  You mention dusty, that the doctors are focussing less on what you are feeling?  Are you suggesting they are not listening to you? Their job is to focus on what is going on, not what you are feeling, (a huge problem, yes) but that is out of your control.  Biopsies are indeed, a very necessary tool in ascertaining whether an abnormality is benign or cancerous.  However, a biopsy can also be unecessary, on something that is "stable" and benign.  A biopsy is not always necessary on a presentation that has clear indications of benign status, many will say a biopsy is the only way.  I swim against the tide on that one, given what has happened to me.  I was treated inappropiately and counselled badly, even though I researched thoroughly.  I can't understand how you feel, but I can empathise with worry and concern when something is not right.  Go see the surgeon, see what he has to say, if he finds an abnormality, (I see an abnormality as something that should not be there) and if that abnormality presents as a benign finding then, you can insist on biopsy to rule out malignancy.  And have the follows up to check the finding.  Whatever you find, I hope you manage to find some peace, within your mind, as opposed to all this worry.

Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2012 03:55PM Sommer43 wrote: I had a complex fibroadenoma removed in March and I am 43.  It was very mobile and quite difficult for the needle to make contact, on the core biopsy, it came back as "unusual" with irrelgular borders.  However, on excison, the mass was confirmed as a complex FA with changes.  It was classed as benign with me being followed up every six months for diagnostic ultra sound, as mmg did not pick up the mass as I have mixed breast density.  Usual for my age, however, it is prevents screening with mammos.  It can be normal, I had three different opinions, from three breast surgeons, I then insisted on seeing the radiologist again, who is the clinical director of screening, who confirmed on his report that it was a complex fibroadenoma.  That was all three months ago now and am back in September for follow up ultra sound!

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2012 02:10AM Sommer43 wrote: This is interesting, not only because I have mixed density breasts, which there are plenty of studies stating that mixed density increases risk of breast cancer which I have studied and read backwards.   I had no idea about breast density until I came here, and while it was initially worrying, because breast density is not discussed here in the UK, however, it is mentioned on pathology reports, then believe me, reading some stuff was pretty scary!   Mixed density breast tissue is pretty normal for a woman of my age, and the reason why the UK have now reduced the national screening age from 50 to 47.  It is only from research that I know about breast density.  Wording is important, and a younger woman who naturally has dense breasts may read that she is likely to be at a risk from breast cancer.  As I am in menopause, there is still time for my breast density to change.   It is an important reminder.

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2012 06:26AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Maisie,  I am in the UK too, and while I cannot assist in what you have found, I can tell you, that you need to insist to your GP that you want a referral back to breast clinic, failing that, did your breast clinic have a breast care nurse attached?  If so, then call them and ask them to refer you back to clinic, as you are getting nowhere with your GP.  It is like the secret service in the UK, getting referrred to breast clinic, and pain killers are not the answer.  I am in the system now, and I did not have problems being referred.  On your previous clinic appointments, were you given the three way testing?  I had the four, Mammogram, US, and the US was where it was picked up as MMG can sometimes miss masses on dense breasts.  Those are the routes I would recommend, and insist to your GP that you want a referral, you have a right to have your concerns addressed.

Posts.Content: Jul 4, 2012 11:03AM Sommer43 wrote: It is not uncommon for palpable masses not to show up on mmg.  Your age, is a factor in that, likely due to your breast density.  I had the same problem, nothing showed up, it is like looking for a grain of sand in a sand storm.  Ultra sound will hopefully pick up the mass and diagnostically grade you for biopsy purposes.  I would imagine, that you will be offered a biopsy, which is not to look for cancer, but to rule out any malignancy, so that's the first piece of advice I can offer you.  Secondly, the wait for the results is agony.  The worry, so prepare yourself for that.  No matter how many people tell you, that 80% biopsies are benign, you will worry.  I can assure you.  If you go down the biiopsy route, then ask when the results will be in, how you will be informed of the results.  That way, as I have seen, you will avoid the uneccessary chasing of results, your clinic may be excellent and send them through to you.  I had to chase mine, although that was my own integrity and how we do it in the UK.  You're at the stage now, where you will be finding out many things and I will advise, that if the word biopsy is mentioned, you may be fearful, but a biopsy is necessary to find out what is going on!  Ultra sound was the best diagnostic tool for me.  Best of luck and come back and let us know how you go!

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 08:12AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Nelly There is what is called a Fine Needle Aspiration, which is like an injection.  This will be performed to aspirate a mass, so if a cyst, fluid is withdrawn and the cyst collapses.  If the mass is hard, then the needle will withdraw cells from the mass to send off to pathology.  In the event of for whatever reason, an FNA comes back as inconclusive, then a core biopsy will be performed.  This is a core needle which is hollow and is able to draw a larger amount of cells.  Both are not painful, I had a local anaesthetic before the core biopsy.  It was painless, all I could feel was pressure.  An excisional biopsy, which can be performed with local or general, is where the whole mass is excised and sent for a final histology analysis.  There are a number of benign conditions that a mass can be too.  Cysts, a previous trauma to your breast, fibroadenomas.  As scary as it is, there is nothing you can do with worry, apart from drive yourself potty.  On ultra sound, were you not made aware of the mass being located?  I was ultra sounded by a radiologist, not a technician.  The mmg was performed by techs, who didn't say anything to me, but the US was where I was told that there was a mass, and I had an ultra sound guided biopsy.  I take it your mass is palpable?

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 05:04PM Sommer43 wrote: HI Kim, My mass was found on US at 1.00pm on the upper quadrant of my breast, which is how they measure the location of any mass that is found in the breast.  To ascertain what it is, you will likely have a biopsy.  I had two biopsies, one a fine needle and as that was inconclusive, in that not enough cells were taken, then I went on to have a core biopsy, which is over and done with in ten minutes or so.  What the radiologist has stated is something that is a bit naughty, that pre-supposes that cancer is exciting and the only sure fire way to find out if any mass is cancerous or benign is to biopsy it!  So there is no way of knowing what it is, until the biopsy, of course radiologists are very skilled at what they read, however, you have to wait for the results of a biopsy to ascertain what the mass is, as hard as that it!  A fibroadenoma, as the lady above has stated, is a benign lump that can grow to quite a size, however, they can also disappear over time...  They are usually oval in shape, with very defined edges, not always palpable, funny little things they are...  They cannot turn cancerous, however, as they contain tissue, that can turn cancerous just like any other tissue.  If palpable, they usually feel smooth and oval and squidgy, not hard, can cause some discomfort, I know in the UK there are lots of disagreement about these things and removing them or leaving them.

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2012 03:36PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi there Shell, I don't think that one is better than the other, both tests have their place for investigating masses.  It is not the tests, it is the individual.  For me, mammogram missed my mass, ultra sound picked it up, and that was down to mixed breast density.  Due to radiation issues, here in the UK, it recommended that nine months should pass before having another mammogram.  Remember that mammogram and ultra sound are not for diagnosis, they cannot diagnose any mass, only biopsy can do that.  If a mass is very palpable, which happened to me also, I didn't need any screening test to see it, the consultant could feel it used ultra sound to guide the biopsy.  I cannot answer your question about masses seen on either tests, whether more or less turn out to be cancer.  All I can say is that mammogramms are unsuitable for women with dense breast tissue.

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2012 01:14PM Sommer43 wrote: Wilson I have had fibrocystic breasts for over ten years, and my cycle has been every 28 days give or take a day or two, up until the last year!  This time, I have had only two weeks grace, between flooding.  I would ask for another blood test, (you only need to book with your nurse at the practice) to check your FSH levels, that will determine whether you are in the peri menopausal period, which can happen.  You may well be entering the peri-menopausal state, which of course at your age, you will be surprised at.  Fibrocystic symptoms are closely related to your menstral cycle and can have an affect on your cycle, given that the condition is related to oestrogen, progestrone and prolactin and symptoms can make your breasts tender and itchy.  This could explain all your pain and the itchiness.  If you're changing GP's then you will undertake all new tests, bloods, urine etc.  Sounds like fibrocystic boobs to me, all the same symptoms I have had since my early 30's.  The symptoms will be at their highest right before your period and should subside once the period arrives, what usually happens with me.  I have had painful breasts for years with it, not to mention painful periods, and lately flooding, when I least expect it, I am currently taking mefanic acid tablets for it, as a blood test has confirmed that my FSH levels are high, which means that my child bearing days are almost over.  I have a decade on you, and have had this condition for over a decade, I only just realised that I have had this, since my recent experiences, with the clinic and the research, but I lived with the pain and now I can safely place the pain I have had on the run up to my period over the last ten years, as fibrocystic.  It sort of helps to give it a name.  To ease symptoms, as hard as it is, I have found that walking, swimming has always helped, tiredness because hormones are acting up, I do fight, but I have sometimes gone to bed early with a heat pad and slept it off.  I have excrutiating pain with periods, and I have also been sterilized at the age of 30.  Do some reading on Fibrocystic breasts, it is not a disease, as once thought, it is a condition that requires a lot of self help and could explain all your recent problems. Have a nice holiday, where are you?  Just booked ours this morning.  We are naffing off South, to a cottage, with my dog, at the end of this month.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 08:15PM Sommer43 wrote: jem4220 Hi there I had a fibroadenoma removed and then had a large mass appear afterwards, although not as long as a year, it was visible to the naked eye though.  Under investigation it was confirmed that it was a fat necrosis and that can come from trauma to the breast.  Given that your young tissue has had so much invasion from surgery, then it may be possible that this is what it is.  Fat necrosis isa benign condition and can form oil cysts, I had one drained a few weeks ago and that relieved the pain and the lump went down.  It does appear that you are a woman who is susceptible to these funny little benign tumours.  Scar tissue is an anomaly, it can grow and while the lumpectomy is a simple procedure, and cosmetically my scar is healed and a fine silver line, some women, I am one of them, do not heal so well from the inside, my body clearly hates being invaded and I still have a small hard lump that is now not painful but has been scanned and is scar tissue.  Also, as Grandma states, it could well be a secondary growth of another fibroadenoma, they can grow back.  Good luck with your appointment and come back and let us know how you go!

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2012 06:00PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Kemps Fibroadenomas are a benign growth associated with estrogen, it is said.  They are more often associated in younger women, of child bearing years, however, it is not considered unusual for a woman to present with one or various at any age.  Some women are more prone to them and some never have them, just like warts or any growth that a human may have.   They are very mobile in the breast, oval in shape, with very defined edges.  An experienced radiologist will recognise a fibroadenoma because of their distinctive shape and appearance.  Some of them grow and anything over 5cm is considered a giant fibroadenoma so likely advice would be a removal.  Some women are not even aware of a fibroadenoma being there, like me, I presented with one at the age of 43 and likely I had it for a long time.  I had mine removed because of my age.  Not because of the risk of breast cancer, but because of the fibroadenoma, blocking any screening of the areas in my breast.  A simple fibroadenoma does not increase your risk of breast cancer.  There are complex fibroadenomas, which very slightly increase the risk, which is what I had.  I think you have made a wise decision in monitoring your FA, you are being very sensible in not going for an uneccessary surgery, you are 31 and that is exactly what I would have done had I been at your age, I would have monitored the mass, rather than opt for surgery as the chances are high that over time it could disappear.   If when you next return, the FA has grown, then you may well be advised removal, if it stays the same, with no changes, then if me, I would have left it.  If it is not causing you any pain, obstructing anywhere and not a fast growing one, then surgery is not necessary.  Hope that helps.

Posts.Content: May 6, 2012 06:44AM - edited May 6, 2012 06:45AM by Sommer43 Candro  I had a fibroadenoma removed nine weeks ago.  Once the knock out stuff was in me, I was out of it and it was all over in 40 mins.  You will be groggy from the anaesthesia,on the night, but recovery is quick.  I was driving within 48 hours, household chores were no problem, and I removed my dressing five days after surgery.  I have a very neat scar, even so soon after surgery, about an 2cms long.  I know it must be scary, I am 43 and only ever had two surgeries in my life, but the thought of it is worse than the actual than the actual event.  You will not have any problems with breast feeding, as a result of this, you may develop some scar tissue, from the surgery, but they cannot turn cancerous, a completely benign condition.   You're so young, you will heal quickly, be back to normal in no time, I was and I have a few years on you.  Our bodies are clever little things, they recover well and you will be absolutely fine!  Good luck

Posts.Content: May 14, 2012 06:15PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi catmac I did have my fibroadenoma removed.  However, I did not know that I had one.  Until I was checked out, I opted for removal, because of my age, anxiety of leaving it in.  I still have pain, which has now been called a fat necrosis, a hard lump that has been ultra sounded, and am told it is benign.  My breast clearly did not like the invasion and am on a follow up to monitor the necrosis.  Not sure why, as everything I have read on necrosis is benign and the body reabsorbs necrosis.  Fibroadenomas, cannot turn cancerous, however, cancer can develop in them, like any other tissue.  So, they are a benign condition.  They are harmless, and can be left and usually are in younger women, unless they are problematic.  Fibroadenomas are moveable, often called breast mice, and are very distinctive in shape and appearance. The margins are very defined, not irregular.  Good luck for Wednesday.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2012 11:30AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi there and welcome to BCO and to the waiting room!  Yep, it's scary stuff, however, the fear, which I have mentioned in another thread is the one to control!  Your doctor is doing exactly as he should, sending you for further investigations!  Your mass could be anything from a cyst to a fibroadenoma to a malignancy and remember that breast cancer is still rare in younger women, not unheard of, but still rare!  Your radiologist will decide on whether to biopsy, there is a rating called the BIRADS system, which determines the need for biopsy.  Birads 0 = Nothing.  Birads 1 =Normal, Birads 2 = Benign, Birads 3 = Indeterminate, Birads 4 = suspicious and Birads 5 = suggests a malignancy is highly suspected and will definitely warrant a biopsy!  Nothing can diagnose cancer, only a biopsy. however, depending on what is seen on the ultra sound, which is a good tool diagnostically for a woman of your age, the radiologist will assess whether you need a biopsy!  If there is a cyst like mass, a needle will be used to make contact to see if the cyst aspirates and fluid will be drawn off, if the needle doesn't collapse the cyst then that is suggestive that you may well need a core biopsy.  This waiting time is hard and nerve racking, but you will get through it and depending on your clinic, you should have your results soon!  Don't read too much into your doctor's face on finding a mass, because that is not an indicator of anything, maybe he has a crestfallen face when he finds anything on anyone.  Is your cycle regular?  Do you have lumpy breasts?  Fibrocystic breasts can cause problems as we age, used to be called a disease now not referred to as a disease, certainly not here in the UK.  Know your cycle, as you will be asked at your appointment when your last period was as that is important in assessing a mass, especially given your age!  It is hard and I don't envy you entering this journey, but the odds are on your side, you don't have to feel isolated, it is routine for the situation and treat it like any other procedure you would have.

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 05:21AM Sommer43 wrote: Oh, it's a process isn't it?  Let me see if I can help you out here.  I have suffered painful breasts for many years, since I was sterilized and ceased the birth control pill. All cyclical.  I have had lumps and bumps, that have come and go.  Having lumps and painful breasts is part of being a woman, there is little we can do about that.  It is part of me, I manage it quite well and I am used to it, as unpleasant as it is.  I have no idea if I have fibrocystic breasts, but I know they have hurt and it is part of my cycle, now am in menopause, there are times I want cut them off myself.  The first sign of pregnancy for me, was sore boobs, how I knew.  As soon as my period arrives, the symptoms disappear and I have had a couple of weeks of relief before it starts again.  For some time now, and those around had noticed it, I kept going under my arm, and my friend was the first one who alerted me to the fact that I kept doing it.  I asked my husband if he had noticed me doing it, and he said yes, but never thought anything else about it.  It was subconscious, however, when my friend picked up on it, and asked me why, I said I could feel a discmfort and that I felt as though something was there.  I eventually went to the doctors who stated she could feel a couple of lumps and on I went for the round of testing.  I won't bore you with the details of that, it is long and tedious and currently my treatment is under investigation here in the UK.  My point to all of this, is, and I am sure many women would agree with me.  We women, should know our bodies.  I knew this discomfort was not cyclical, I knew that it had been there for sometime and it took a while for my brain to catch up with me.  The fact you are convinced that you have something there and feel that you are not being listened to, is distressing in itself.  The fact that you are nursing, could be related to this, however, and the possibility is that, all the medics you are seeing are simply putting it down to your breasts being busy and lactating. Hence, why you are being sidelined. So, stop poking yourself, as it can make things worse, but give it a couple of months and study your breast changes, make a journal of events, check yourself once a month, keep calm and see if there is a pattern.  One of the reasons, why I felt frustrated at the beginning is that I wasn't getting any answers from the medics, because I was not asking the right questions. Educate yourself on your breasts and your body and see if there is a pattern of events. Then, in a couple of months, or so, if there is something there, you have proof, get to a doctor, armed with information, not just on breast cancer, but on the benign conditions that are out there, and if you go in looking as though you mean business, then you will get somewhere. As women here, will tell you, there are many myths out there, about breast cancer, and one of them is that, pain is a good sign of it not being malignant. Bollocks, there are thousands here who have had pain prior to diagnosis. A lump or thickening can be any number of benign conditions also, so don't convince yourself you have cancer, when you don't know. You owe it to that little one, to ensure you are healthy, do the legwork yourself, help yourself, educate yourself and ask any questions here that you will get answers to, nobody minds. I hope that helps you.
Posts.Title: the girl who cried lump: trusting yourself vs. professionals youngmomoftwo youngmomoftwo

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 06:40AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi back YMOF2 To receive peace and release ourselves from worry, we have to educate ourselves about our bodies.  If we went to the best breast surgeon in the world, we may still feel the same.  If our lymph nodes in our neck are swollen, and we have a cold, we take that as acceptable.  Lymph nodes do swell in malignant cases, yet lymphodema, can be diagnosed without being cancerous.  It is not always associated with cancer.  If I am feeling a bit off, tired and run down, my body aches, my underarms hurt and my head hurts, yet I never once think I might have a brain tumour, why do we do it with our boobs?  Breast cancer is rare, still, the fact that most of the women on here, have been diagnosed, they are in the minority, still, (although, I am sure, rare doesn't feel that way to them, they are ones suffering and being rare is of no relevance to a person who is suffering)  we all think it is cancer when we first find something.  If you educate yourself, about your breasts, (they are not just there for men to play with!) what is in them, find out what ducts, lobes, fatty tissue, etc goes on, how they work, you will be in a much better position to determine that your inner voice is correct and not doubt yourself, resulting in sleepless nights and worry.  It is about educating ourselves, with how our bodies work, so that when a lump or mass, is found, we don't panic ourselves, we don't panic our family and we don't torture ourselves.  Most women, that I have seen come here on first finding a lump are scared shitless, because that is what they think, I did.  I even cancelled a family party because of what "might" happen.  It was a ridiculous way to carry on.  Get things in perspective, give your hubby a hug and tell him that you're sorry for worrying him and that you will approach your concerns in a different manner.  Monitor your body, find out how it works, and then take any concerns to your doctor.  It's the way forward and makes for a much more peaceful existence.  If, the worst outcome is a malignancy, then you will have a whole new set of feelings to deal with and here, with the women who are in the eye of the storm is the place to be.  It worked for me, and if only one woman listens to that, then I am a happy bunny.
Posts.Title: the girl who cried lump: trusting yourself vs. professionals youngmomoftwo youngmomoftwo

Posts.Content: May 22, 2012 07:31AM Sommer43 wrote: You ladies are so lovely and it does pain me to see so much worry in a world of misunderstanding, ill health and sadness.  I am in no way suggesting that my way is correct, that's what worked for me and I have been there.  I drove my children mad, my husband, it was all so distressing for them.  When I stepped back and looked at how my kids were beginning to avoid me, because I was so consumed with frustration and that no person was listening to me, they were on the verge of having me committed.  It is terrifying, absolutely frightening when things happen to us and we hear the "cancer" word.  I read alot of the stage IV forums, and there I see ladies who are living the fear that I felt and I oft think, how do they manage that?  With small children?  Where do they find the courage?  I am so far away from that mindset, then I see the ladies laughing and talking about the same things we talk about.  It is about the mind, and when it runs riot, it certainly runs riot.  It shows us, how frail our minds are, the torment that we put ourselves through.  Looking for bad news, hell, counsellors would make a fortune.  Our health will always be our best asset, it is up to us to look after that, mentally and physically.  The doctors are there, for when it goes wrong, when our health is threatened.  You wouldn't allow a person to live rent free in your garden, using your water and taking space up on your lawn, why allow something to live in our heads rent free, evict it and approach it in a different way.  We can all lay our hands on statistics, women in their younger years being diagnosed.  I heard it all the time when I came here, DON'T GOOGLE, 80% of all lumps are benign, it didn't help me.  I didn't give a crap about statistics, I did google, but then I learned what material to read.

Posts.Content: Jun 5, 2012 07:54AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi georgie and welcome to BCO.  Scary isn't it, when we find something?  There is a myriad of "things" that this change could be.  You are doing the right thing in getting it checked out.  We all think the worst.  You're not alone in that.  There is plenty of reading to be done, but be careful what you enter as your search terms, if you enter breast cancer symptoms, then you will end up convincing yourself you have breast cancer.  Your mind will tell you that, when in fact, the reality is, only a biopsy can tell you whether what you have, is a cancerous route.  Try to keep that thought and hold onto it.  In the meantime, ask any questions, change to a non wired soft bra, I am still wearing them now, as I monitor my boobs and since surgery.  Nobody sees it, only me.

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 12:52PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi georgie Am sorry to read that you are still anxious, but an anxious time it is, waiting for a mammogram.  I have accepted that my lumps and bumps, which are very apparent are "normal tissue" after four months of insisting that I have my axillary area sonogrammed, which I did on Friday.  I had a thorough examination, all at my behest, with a detailed US of the whole breast and despite three swollen lymph nodes, a fat necrosis, adenosis, I am on a benign path with a three month follow up.  It has taken some time to get my mind where I am today, with some relief, that I now know what I am dealing with. It has made me aware and not to look and keep feeling my boobs all the time.  Normal tissue can hurt, while pain needs to be looked into, if it is found to be normal then we should accept, or drive ourselves insane with worry.  You are having a mammagram, know that you are being seen and screened, and whatever comes back from that, am sure you will be looked after by those charged with your care.  It is one of the hardest things, waiting and I wish I could simply hand over to you, a good dose of calm at this difficult time, knowing what I was like when I was where you are right now.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2012 01:44PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Wilson,. You certainly haven't annoyed me, I hear you girl, frustration is the pits and if we feel that we are not being listened to, well, we do blow up!  No, you don't need to prove what you have, at all, that's the doctor's job! That said, a doctor's job is to rule out malignant possibilities, not look for them.  They are human beings, they feel like we do, they bleed like we do and if a patient is distressed and claiming they have something that they cannot see evidence of, then they will too, become frustrated. But  why should we live with chronic pain and irritability, I am with you.  When I was first going through the mill with the round of appointments, I convinced myself of all sorts, our minds run riot, when it was something very simple and easy and not at all concerning, although I am being monitored, this is the best result that could have come through all of this.  I asked for a second opinion from my GP, I received this, no problem, she found me another breast consultant as I didn't feel reassured with the first one I saw.  I read somewhere on here, I think it was Marie, who had written it, to a lady who was convinced she had breast cancer, on finding a lump, now we all think that, I did and am sure am not alone there.  But as Marie pointed out and I thought it was brilliant, if we think we have something, and we look up that particular problem, then what we read will be fitting to what we think have.  It is about mind control and bringing ourselves back to the here and now, you don't know what is causing these awful symptoms, and you need the medical profession to try to find out what is going on. Of course you can rant here, I don't think of all the 1000's of members mind in the slightest, remember, they too, have been in your position, the frustration, the pain, the worrying, the wondering...  But self diagnosis, is like a child wielding a sword, dangerous, and takes us to places where we lose all control, I have seen it, experienced it.  I would spend days, worrying, reading until my hubbie ticked me off, he was being affected by it, friends were avoiding me...  I have been where you are, by all means rant, by all means shout it out, but people will chime in and advise you, that's the risk you run when you're on a public forum...  I have a surgeon now, who is just fantastic with me, and he stated to me, that one sentence from a medical staff member can change a person's life, he's very aware of that and we get on great and he has my ultimate trust, in how he guides me through each and every step and sometimes, I have had to wait for him to call me back, but now I know that when he can, he will get around to returning my call.  I think, from what you have written, you lack confidence in your GP and this is contributing to what already is a very worrying time for you.  This is why I suggested speaking with practice manager.  Write them a nice letter, sod the 1000 piece jigsaw puzzle, to the practice manager, asking for a telephone conversation with her/him or even better a meeting, to get your points and needs across.  The GP and the surgery are bound by a duty of care, and if you are failed in that, then you have every right, as a patient on the NHS to be heard.

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 03:43PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi there Isa, I had an excisional biopsy (a lumpectomy) on a fibroadenoma.  I am left with a neat scar, a small indent in my breast, which would only be noticeable if I pointed it out to a person who was looking at me dangling my boobs when bent over and as the only person who would see me in such an incompomising position, is my husband he doesn't care.  As you are so young, you must be feeling so worried about scarring, the procedure itself, but let me reassure you, it is not that bad.  I was anxious when my dressing came off and I was totally surprised.  If there is indentation from the removal, then new tissue will fill it.  I am not big breasted, a 34b, and these days bras are so well designed they will cover up any non fills.   Fibroadenomas do not turn cancerous, nor are they a pre-requisite for cancer problems as you age.  They don't heighten your chances of developing breast cancer alone, however, it is important that you are aware of your breasts and the conditions that can develop.  I am 43 and had never heard of these things till two months ago, yet is it likely I have had this for a long time and it has simply moved to the surface due to hormonal changes happening in my body.  They are estrogen linked, hence they are common in younger women.  While the cause of breast cancer is still not known, I am certainly aware of all that's going on in my body now, without being paranoid about it.  This will give you an opportunity to be breast aware, which while I did many self exams, I never knew of the many changes that our boobs go through...  I am only learning now...  At least my daughter can now be more aware than I ever was...   You're young, these are common, don't spend your life worrying about what could happen later, have them removed if this is what has been recommended to you...  Be breast aware and know that these are common, benign and harmless...

Posts.Content: Jun 22, 2012 03:44PM Sommer43 wrote: I too went through the PALS pathway and I gained a re-examination.   Wazzle, While there is the elephant in the room about younger women, it is rare and I have said earlier to another young woman, it is not to be dismissed.  Hormones are powerful things and it is likely that this is causing your breast issues.  This is where you should become more breast aware now, and note your cycle, am assuming 16 months down the line after birth your cycle is back to normal?  The thickening you feel could well be down to hormone relating to pregnancy, while pregnancy and birth are normal events, it is still traumautic and women's bodies are never the same post birth and pregnancy as they are ante birth and pregnancy.  What you have going on, could well be hormonal.  While it seems as though you are being brushed away, it is actually fact that hormones are responsible for a lot of goings on in our bodies.  So, my advice is, keep a note of your cycle, when it happens and check your breasts once pre-cycle so that you can feel what is cyclical and then check them again 3-7 dats after the end of your period, to see what is left.  It is important to know that the best time for checking our breasts is at the end of our cycle, when our hormones are sleeping, which is why the question is always asked, date of our last period.  It gives the medics a good idea of what is hormonal and what is not.  Back pain is common after child-birth and mine has never been the same my last child, that's the price we have to pay for being a woman.  All of this is only my opinion, based on what you have written, not a medical opinion, only as a woman who has been through this.   Christine? I hope you get good results from your own consultation.

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 02:02PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi there and welcome to BCO.  Scary isn't it?  But you're not alone, there are plenty here who have been where you are now, right now.  We all, try to prepare ourselves for the worst possible outcome and once the outcome is in, we then wonder about that and then we wonder what will happen and on and on it goes. If you're going to read only on breast cancer, then you may do a great job of convincing yourself you have breast cancer, before a diagnosis.  Because you are at pre-biopsy stage, then you are likely thinking that your lump is malignant.  I can happily tell you, that there are also many benign conditions that are also out there and if I have learned anything from my time on the same journey you're about to undertake, it is that, looking on the bleak side, is not good for my or my family's mental state.  I also, know why, many people think that if they prepare themselves for the worst news, then if they get good news they will feel better, and if it is bad news, then they have somehow prepared themselves for the event.  Thing is, as many women will tell you, who have been diagnosed with a malignant path, is that nothing could have prepared for how they feel, when this happens.  There are lots of women here, who will hold you up through this time, of wondering, waiting, anxious time.  You can vent your anger, frustrations here, if that's what you need to do, by all means, but try not to think the worst and if you're going to research, then choose your research wisely.

I have a benign condition that is now being rescanned, due to educating myself with the good women here and the research I have done for my own end.  Initially, when my doctor told me I had a lump, I thought the worst, my husband did also.  But four months down the line, I am now in a much better place and the fear that I had initially has subsided.  It is about keeping things in perspective and I wish politicians would stay out of health care.  It makes it so much harder for the masses to do anything because it is all a money issue.  I still have my problem, in fact I have a bigger one, under investigation as I have had inappropiate treatment, however, I am not in the mind of sueing my health authority, I do realise that events happen and we cannot always have what we want.  But, and I stress this, 300 and something odd posts here, in the NDBW forum, I see many women come in and do exactly what I did.  Google "Lump in breast" and off they go.  They have cancer.  Biopsy, as a term, is always associated with cancer.  It is not looking for cancer, it is ruling out cancer and I have learned that.  Now, I can speak with the medics and I have educated myself, use their terms, and I ask the questions, dress smartly when I go and give that all important eye contact, which means "Don't think for a moment I am leaving this office, until I am satisfied with what you're telling me"  I had to educate myself, because otherwise my husband would have been locked up for throttling the consultant we saw, he went beserk when we got home after one appointment.  Now, I have banned him from coming with me.

Posts.Content: May 21, 2012 08:21AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi michelle, Don't be frightened, you are having what is a very simple procedure.  That is necessary.  Fibroadenomas can grow at an alarming rate and while still benign, a benign tumour that is growing can cause problems.  The difference between benign and malignant is that benign is a mild and non progressive disease, as opposed to a malignancy which can be aggressive and spread.  Benign tumours do not have the ability to metastasize, cancer does.  A biopsy, like any procedure is not a 100% certainty that something more sinister, is lurking.  I agree that this needs to be excised, so that a final histology can be done and if, if there is any chance of a malignancy, it is out and at least you will know what you dealing with.  As worrying as it is, this is the right course of action that you're having.  Are you having a general anaesthetic?  I had one for mine, recovery was swift... More groggy than anything from the anaesthetic.  Nothing to apologise for, you're scared and anxious, I was too.  Let us know how it goes, your results, and how you are tomorrow.  Big hugs.

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2012 05:35AM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Tina,  Fibroadenomas cannot turn cancerous, they are a hard, moveable,mobile, benign tumour and very common in younger women, but a woman of any age can present with one.  Or a few.  Again, little is known about the cause of them, but they are thought to be linked to oestrogen, hence why common in younger women.  I presented with one at the age of 43, yet likely that I had it a long time, I had it removed and tested for peace of mind, due to my age, nothing more than that.  It is important that it is biopsied, to ensure it is a fibroadenoma, that will put your mind at rest.  They are harmless, but can grow to become giant fibroadenomas, which will likely be excised. It is recommended that women in their 40's have them removed, due to them being a blocker during screening.  They can also disappear, so depending on your age, after biopsy, you may well be advised to leave alone and watch and wait.  No point having surgery unless they become a problem.

Posts.Content: May 18, 2012 04:10PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Jaye, Lovely to see you.  I asked, because I have been battling, truly battling, with the consultants, two of the swines, the first one, who missed my initial problem.  What I couldn't get my head around, was this fat necrosis, being so large from my excisional, when the mass, which was 11mm by 4mm, was only 5mm under the skin.  I think and so does the breast care nurse, who I spent an hour on the phone with, that the original lump has been overlooked.  So am back for another scan, another biopsy, as the raidiologist, who is the clinical director of screening (I tracked him down on a social networking site, can't escape the old Sommer) and wrote to him directly, as I had left three messages on his secretary's line, ordered a biopsy and guess what?  The consultant didn't do one.  Tsk, tsk.  Now, I still think it is a benign progression, am not keen on yet another procedure, but it cannot be avoided.  And with the clinic I attend, the previous clinical director of breast screening, in 2008, out of 248 women, misdaignosed 18 women, so they have to be on the ball.  They will be laying the red carpet out for me, they have had enough press attention, and I found this out because I googled his name.  What was attached?  My clinical director of breast screening, took over from the guy who missed the cancers in those 18 women.  What a bloody performance I have had.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 12:24PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi there, Jaye, I had an excisonal biopsy nine weeks ago.  I have more pain now, than I did after the surgery.  I had to return to clinic, with another large mass, which was ultra sounded and told it is fat necrosis.  Apparently, this is something that can take time to go away and the body is likely to absorb this mass.  I have seen no improvements at all, and as time goes on, even though am simply accepting as problems after surgery, which I didn't expect then I am willing to see it through, as I do not want anymore surgery, it would be the last resort, as long as it is fat necrosis.  The incision from the surgery healed very well. I took my dressing off after five days, I felt fine, was driving again after 48 hours and apart from a couple of co-deine, all was well, till about two weeks after and this happened.  I did experience like a knitting together, if that at all makes a sense, from within, it sort of felt busy...   Sending you good healing thoughts, Jaye.

Posts.Content: May 7, 2012 03:13PM Sommer43 wrote: Hi Srrme, At age 22, breast cancer is very rare, while it is worrying, your chances are very slim.  If the lumps are smooth, moveable, then there is very possibilty that you have fibroadenomas.  Which are benign lumps that are very common in young women, are estrogen fuelled and can come and go throughout your life.  Given your age, you are breast feeding, and you have a 5 month old baby that your body is settling down after birth... Get the lumps checked to be on the safe side, and good luck.
